message_1: Suppose we have an elliptic curve defined by the equation y^2 = x^3 + 7x + 10 over the finite field GF(19). Let P = (3, 1) be a point on the curve. Find 3P, where 3P denotes the sum of P with itself twice (i.e., P + P + P).
message_2:
To find 3P, we first need to find 2P and then add P to it. 

Step 1: Find 2P
To find 2P, we use the formula for point doubling on an elliptic curve:

λ = (3x₁² + a) / 2y₁ (mod p)

Here, x₁ = 3, y₁ = 1, a = 7, and p = 19.

λ = (3(3)² + 7) / 2(1) (mod 19)
λ = (27 + 7) / 2 (mod 19)
λ = 34 / 2 (mod 19)
λ = 17 (mod 19)

Now, we find the new x and y coordinates for 2P:

x₂ = λ² - x₁ - x₁ (mod p)
y₂ = λ(x₁ - x₂) - y₁ (mod p)

x₂ = 17² - 3 - 3 (mod 19)
x₂ = 289 - 6 (mod 19)
x₂ = 283 (mod 19)
x₂ = 11

y₂ = 17(3 - 11) - 1 (mod 19)
y₂ = 17(-8) - 1 (mod 19)
y₂ = -137 - 1 (mod 19)
y₂ = -138 (mod 19)
y₂ = 9

So, 2P = (11, 9).

Step 2: Find 3P
To find 3P, we add P to 2P. We use the formula for point addition on an elliptic curve:

λ = (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁) (mod p)

Here, x₁ = 3, y₁ = 1, x₂ = 11, y₂ = 9, and p = 19.

λ = (9 - 1) / (11 - 3) (mod 19)
λ = 8 / 8 (mod 19)
λ = 1 (mod 19)

Now, we find the new x and y coordinates for 3P:

x₃ = λ² - x₁ - x₂ (mod p)
y₃ = λ(x₁ - x₃) - y₁ (mod p)

x₃ = 1² - 3 - 11 (mod 19)
x₃ = 1 - 14 (mod 19)
x₃ = -13 (mod 19)
x₃ = 6

y₃ = 1(3 - 6) - 1 (mod 19)
y₃ = -3 - 1 (mod 19)
y₃ = -4 (mod 19)
y₃ = 15

So, 3P = (6, 15).
